This is an Accepted Manuscript, which has been through the Royal Society of Chemistry peer review process and has been accepted for publication.
Accepted Manuscripts are published online shortly after acceptance, before technical editing, formatting and proof reading. Using this free service, authors can make their results available to the community, in citable form, before we publish the edited article. We will replace this Accepted Manuscript with the edited and formatted Advance Article as soon as it is available.
You can find more information about Accepted Manuscripts in the Information for Authors.
Please note that technical editing may introduce minor changes to the text and/or graphics, which may alter content. The journal’s standard Terms & Conditions and the Ethical guidelines still apply. In no event shall the Royal Society of Chemistry be held responsible for any errors or omissions in this Accepted Manuscript or any consequences arising from the use of any information it contains.

Nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites have been synthesized with the seed-assisted method
showing remarkably improved performance in methanol-to-olefin reaction.

COMMUNICATION
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 1
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Received 00th January 20xx, Accepted 00th January 20xx
DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
www.rsc.org/
Seeding induced nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites: cost-
effective synthesis and superior MTO performance†
Qiming Sun, a Ning Wang, a Risheng Bai, a Xiaoxin Chen, a and Jihong Yu* a

sections.heading: A facile and cost-effective strategy has been developed to synthesize nano-sized SAPO-34 zeolite catalysts with intracrystalline meso-macroporosity as well as high crystallinity
sections.text:
and product yield via the seed-assisted method using triethylamine as the sole template. Significantly, compared to the conventional micron-sized microporous SAPO-34 zeolites, the nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites show superior performance in methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction with 4-folds prolonged catalytic lifetime and remarkably improved selectivity of ethylene and propylene reaching up to 85.0%, which is among the highest catalytic performance in MTO reaction ever reported under similar conditions.
Zeolites as the most important industrial solid catalysts have attracted extensive attention.1-6 To overcome the pore size limitation of zeolites, a great interest has emerged recently in the development of nano-sized and hierarchical zeolites because of their remarkably enhanced accessibility and improved catalytic activity in various reactions suffering from steric and/or diffusional limitations.7-8 In the past decades, SAPO-34 zeolites with the CHA topological structure have been inspiring great interests because of their excellent catalytic performance in the methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction, which has proven to be a promising route to produce basic petrochemicals from nonoil resources such as coal, natural gas, and even biomass using methanol as an intermediate.9-11 However, SAPO-34 zeolites often suffer from the rapid deactivation during methanol conversion due to the limitation of mass transport and the coke species blocking the channels and covering the active sites.12 Previous studies have shown that decreasing the crystal size can suppress the catalyst deactivation and enhance the catalytic activity in MTO
reaction. 13-16 In general, tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH) can be used as template to synthesize the nano-sized SAPO-34 catalysts. 17-19 However, the expensive synthetic cost restricts their industrial application. Triethylamine (TEA) with the lower price can also be used to prepare the SAPO-34 zeolites. 20, 21 However, the SAPO-34 zeolites synthesized by using TEA as templates always possess the micron sized, lower crystallinity, and impurity with the intergrowth structure of the CHA/AEI, which are unfavourable for the MTO reaction. 22, 23 Hence, synthesis of pure nano-sized SAPO-34 zeolites with high crystallinity using TEA as template is of great both fundamental and practical significance.
On the other hand, introducing the mesopore or/and macropore into the microporous SAPO-34 zeolite crystals to form the hierarchical structure can greatly improve the diffusion limitations of mass transport, retard the coke formation, and enhance the catalytic performance.24-26 Recently, various strategies have been used to prepare the hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites by mean of, for example, softtemplating methods,25-27 hard-templating methods,28 posttreatment method29 and other methods.30-32 These hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts show remarkably enhanced performance in MTO reaction compared to the conventional microporous counterparts. However, the complicated synthesis procedure, high synthesis cost, reduced crystallinity, low solid yields as well as the extra environmental pollution because of removing the meso-/macroporous templates hinder their further largescale industrial production. Therefore, developing a facile and cost-effective method to synthesize hierarchical SAPO-34 with high yields and absence of extra meso-/macroporous templates remains a challenge. Notably, up to now, the SAPO34 zeolites with both hierarchical structure and nano-sized crystal size using TEA as the sole template have seen no reported.
In this work, nano-sized SAPO-34 zeolite catalysts with intracrystalline meso-macroporosity, high crystallinity and product yields have been for the first time successfully synthesized via the seed-assisted method using TEA as template under one-step hydrothermal conditions. The as-

sections.heading: COMMUNICATION Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
synthesized SAPO-34 zeolites exhibit nano-sized hollow morphology and hierarchical structure and show remarkably enhanced catalytic performance in MTO reaction with about 4- folds prolonged catalytic lifetime and more than 10% improvement of selectivity for C2H4 and C3H6 than the conventional micron-sized microporous SAPO-34 zeolites.
Figure 1. a) XRD patterns b) N2 adsorption/desorption c) DFT pore size distribution curves and d) pore size distributions measurement determined by mercury intrusion porosimetry of micron-sized microporous (SM) and nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 (SH1, SH2, and SH3) samples.
The nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts (SH1, SH2 and SH3) were synthesized by seed-assisted method using TEA as template with the molar composition of 1.0Al2O3: 1.0P2O5: 4.7TEA: xSiO2: 70H2O: 8.0 wt% Seeds (x=0.4, 0.6 and 0.8) under hydrothermal conditions at 200 °C for 36 h. The seeds with pure CHA structure were obtained with the molar composition of 1.0Al2O3: 1.2P2O5: 2.0 TEAOH: 0.6SiO2: 40H2O as reported in our previous work. 15 SEM and TEM images reveal that the
seeds exhibit uniform nanosheets-like morphology with the thickness of 20-50 nm (Fig. S1, ESI†). For comparison, the conventional microporous SAPO-34 (SM) was synthesized with the same molar composition of sample SH3 without adding seeds.
The XRD patterns of all of the samples are shown in Fig. 1a. Samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 show the typical diffraction peaks of the CHA structures, indicating the phase purity. However, sample SM shows an apparent shoulder peak at ca. 20.7° revealing the mixture phase of the framework type of CHA and AEI. 23 Moreover, the values of relative crystallinity reveal that the crystallinities of samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 are higher than that of sample SM. This indicates that using the nano sheet-like SAPO-34 zeolites with pure CHA structure as seeds is much beneficial for the crystallization and generating pure phase of SAPO-34 products (Table 1). In addition, samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 have very high yields of more than 80%, which is over 30% improvement than that of microporous sample SM, thus promising their large-scale production in future (Table 1).
Table 1. Framework composition, porosity, relative crystallinity, and product yields of micron-sized microporous SAPO-34 (SM) and nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 (SH1, SH2, and SH3) samples.
Samples Molar
Compositiona

SM Si0.16Al0.43P0.41O2 523 489 34 0.23 64 50.2 SH1 Si0.10Al0.48P0.42O2 592 578 14 0.28 100 80.7
SH2 Si0.13Al0.45P0.42O2 573 558 15 0.27 87 81.1 SH3 Si0.15Al0.46P0.39O2 556 536 20 0.27 81 81.6
a Measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer; b SBET (total surface area) calculated by applying the BET equation using the linear part (0.05<P/Po<0.30) of the adsorption isotherm; c Smicro (micropore area) and Vmicro (micropore volume) calculated using the t-plot method. d The relative crystallinity is calculated based on the intensity of the three strongest peaks (2θ=9.5 o, 16.0 o, and 20.5 o) in the XRD patterns. e Yield= (w1-w2)/w3, (w1, w2, and w3 are the weight of calcined sample, seed and theoretical SAPO-34 sample, respectively.
SEM images show that all of the samples exhibit the cubiclike morphologies, while, their crystal sizes are obviously different (Fig. 2). Samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 synthesized with seed-assisted method present remarkably decreased crystal

sections.heading: Journal Name COMMUNICATION
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 3
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
sizes of about 300-800 nm which are only about one tenth of conventional microporous sample SM. The TEM images clearly reveal that the samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 represent the centrehollowed morphology with mesopore and macropores extending along the entire crystals with the sizes of ca. 20-200 nm (Fig. 3).
Figure 3. TEM images of nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 samples: SH1 (a-c), SH2 (d-f), and SH3 (g-i).
All of the samples show the type-I N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 1b). Compared to the conventional micronsized microporous samples, the uptakes near saturation pressure in the isotherms can be observed in the nano-sized hierarchical samples, indicating that the hierarchical SAPO-34 samples possess smaller crystal sizes as well as some mesopores and macropores. 32 In addition, the hierarchical samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 exhibit larger microporous areas (536- 578 m 2 /g) and volumes (0.27-0.28 cm 3 /g) than that of microporous sample SM (489 m 2 /g and 0.23 cm 3 /g), revealing that the hierarchical samples possess the higher crystallinity than microporous counterpart. The detailed porosity data are summarized in Table 1. The DFT pore distributions further demonstrated the existence of mesopores and macropores (25-200 nm) in samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 in accordance with the observation of TEM images (Fig. 1c). Fig. 1d shows the macropore size distributions of hierarchical SAPO-34 samples determined by mercury intrusion porosimetry. It can be seen that there are macropore ca. 100-300 nm existed in the hierarchical SAPO-34 samples in accordance with the TEM observations. In addition, the macropores ca. 800 nm can be also observed in hierarchical SAPO-34 samples, which are attributed to the void spaces between the nano-sized crystals.
The hierarchical samples have slightly higher weight loss than that of microporous sample indicating that more templates are introduced into the SAPO-34 zeolite which is probably beneficial for the crystallization (Fig. S2, ESI†). The Si contents of samples SH1, SH2, and SH3 increase with the increase of added silica in the initial synthetic gels. Different Si contents can remarkably affect the coordination environment of Si atoms and acidity of samples. The solid-state 29 Si MAS NMR spectra demonstrate that samples SM and SH3 exhibit diverse silicon species, while sample SH1 with the lowest Si content just
possesses the Si(0Si4Al) and Si(1Si3Al) units indicating that decreasing Si doping amount can avoid the formation of Si(3Si1Al) and (Si(4Si0Al)) units (Fig. S3, ESI†). 33
NH3-TPD
analyses reveal that the acidic strength and concentration in strong acid sites reduce with the decrease of the Si content (Fig. S4, ESI†). 25 Notably, all of the samples exhibit the similar solid-state 27 Al MAS NMR spectra giving the strong peak at 36 ppm attributed to the tetrahedral aluminum atoms (Fig. S5, ESI†), which indicates that the formation of hierarchical structures does not change the coordination environment of Al atoms and further demonstrates that the crystallinity of hierarchical samples keeps intact.
Figure 4. TEM images of nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 samples SH1 synthesized with different crystallization times at (a)1 h, (b) 2 h, (c) 3 h, (d) 4 h, (e) 5 h, (f) 6 h, (g) 12 h, (h) 24 h and (i) 36 h. Scale bar=200 nm.
In order to investigate the formation of nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 crystals, the samples SH1 synthesized with different crystallization times are studied. Fig. 4 shows the TEM images of samples SH1 crystallized from 1 h to 36 h. According to the TEM images, the proposed process for the formation of nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites is shown in Scheme 1. At the beginning of crystallization stage, the nanosheet-like seeds are covered inside of the initial gel and etched into fragments by the gel, and then the SAPO-34 zeolites crystallize epitaxially on the surface of seeds as shown in Fig. 4a and 4b. Subsequently, the residual seeds and precursors further crystallize both on the outside and inside of the SAPO-34 zeolites which thicken the SAPO-34 crystals as shown in Fig. 4c-4e. During the process of crystallization, the seed crystals are continually dissolved into the gel phase introducing more void spaces and the crystal growth further proceeds on the internal and outside surface. 34 As a result, the hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites are finally obtained (Fig. 4f-4i). It also can be seen that after the crystallization time reaches up to 6h, the morphology of sample SH1 almost keeps unchanged, indicating the crystallization of samples is nearly completed, which is in accordance with their XRD analyses (Fig. S6 and Table S1, ESI†). According to the molar compositions of sample SH1 synthesized with different crystallization times, the Si contents decrease from 1h to 6h due to the decrease of amorphous in generated solid products and the gradual

sections.heading: COMMUNICATION Journal Name
sections.text:
4 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
dissolution of the residual seeds with higher Si content than the generated crystals. After 6h, the molar compositions of samples remain the same. In addition, the dissolved seeds can also generate the primary particles and remarkably decrease the crystal sizes due to the Ostwald ripening mechanism. 35
Scheme 1. Schematic of the process for the formation of nano-sized hierarchical SAPO34 zeolites.
Catalytic tests of methanol conversion were performed at 673 K in a fixed-bed reactor over micron-sized microporous catalyst (SM) and nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts (SH1, SH2, and SH3). The selectivities of ethylene and propylene and lifetimes of samples are shown in Fig.5. The detailed selectivity of products and catalytic results are given in Fig. S7-S10, and Table S2. Compared to the micron-sized microporous catalyst, the nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts exhibit the remarkably prolonged catalytic lifetime. Notably, nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts SH1 with the lowest acidity shows the longest lifetime reaching up to 586 min, which is 4- folds higher than that of micron-sized microporous catalyst (146 min), and also higher than other hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts SH2 (466 min) and SH3 (306 min) with higher silicon content. Moreover, the lifetime of SH1 catalyst is also comparable with the nanosheets-like seeds (606 min).15
Signficantly, the selectivity of C2H4 and C3H6 of nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts are much higher than the micron-sized microporous catalyst. Especially, hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts SH1 exhibits the highest selectivity of C2H4 and C3H6 up to 85.0% which is above 10% higher than that of conventional counterpart (73.6%) and higher than that of hierarchical catalysts SH2 (82.5%) and SH3 (80.5%) as well as nanosheets-like seeds (79.8%). Notably, the selectivity of C2H4 and C3H6 over catalysts SH1 is among the highest catalytic performance in MTO reaction ever reported under similar condition. 15, 32
Compared to the conventional catalyst SM, the remarkably improved catalytic performance of catalyst SH1 can be attributed to the reduced crystal size, the generated hierarchical structure, the improved crystallinity as well as the decreased acid strength and concentration. The smaller crystal size and hierarchical structure of crystals can greatly benefit the diffusion of reactant and products from interior of crystals
to the outside and retard the coke formation rate, and thus prolong the lifetime and enhance the selectivity of light olefins. 15 In addition, the improved crystallinity and microporous value are in favour of the shape selectivity of products and generating more light olefins. Furthermore, the decrease acidity can also suppress the coking rate and improve the catalytic activities. 36 Hydrogen transfer index (HTI, C3H8/C3H6) indicates that the decreased acidity of catalysts can greatly reduce the second hydrogen transformation of generated olefin products and improve the selectivity of light olefins (Fig. S11, ESI†). 26
Figure 5. a) Lifetimes and b) selectivity of ethylene and propylene over micron-sized microporous (SM) and nano-sized hollow hierarchical SAPO-34 (SH1, SH2, and SH3) catalysts. Experimental conditions: WHSV = 2 h-1, T = 673 K, catalyst weight = 300 mg.
Coke species analyses show that the coke species retained in the deactivated SAPO-34 catalysts after MTO conversion are aromatic compounds in line with the hydrocarbon pool mechanism (Fig. S12, ESI†).37, 38 Furthermore, the hierarchical catalyst SH1 exhibits the lowest coking rate (0.07 mg/min) among all of the catalysts, which is just one third of the conventional microporous catalyst (Table S3, ESI†).
In conclusion, a facile and cost-effictive seed-assisted method has been for the first time successfully developed to synthesize nano-sized hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites with intracrystalline meso-macroporosity using TEA as the sole template under one-step hydrothermal conditions. The nanosized hierarchical SAPO-34 zeolites possess remarkably decreased crystal size, higher crystallinity, and improved yield compared to the conventional counterpart. Significantly, thanks to the enhanced diffusion efficiency and decreased

sections.heading: Journal Name COMMUNICATION
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 5
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
acidity, the obtained hierarchical catalysts exhibit remarkably improved catalytic performance in MTO reaction with about 4- folds prolonged catalytic lifetime and more than 10% improvement of selectivity for C2H4 and C3H6 than the conventional micron-sized microporous SAPO-34, which is also among the highest catalytic performance in MTO reaction ever reported under similar condition. This work demonstrates a novel, simple and cost-effective synthetic route to prepare nano-sized hierarchical zeolites with excellent MTO performance, which will open a new perspective for the synthesis and application of nano-sized hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts. More importantly, the simple synthesis process, high zeolite yield, and superior catalytic activity promise their large-scale industrial application in future.
